6qSKzsYU-GcNDtmjx0uHLg.text: Came here with a friend for afternoon tea and ordered the afternoon tea set. The scones and egg sandwiches were pretty good, went very well with the jam and butter provided. The banana bread was a little disappointing though. We ordered earl grey tea, mojito and sangria (2 drinks for $15 promotion) and spent a good 3 hours there chilling. The restaurant wasnt too crowded and had a lovely atmosphere. Definitely worth a visit!

Pog25rn6YZ3OoysF58lvHQ.text: The lunch sets are a steal at just $19.90++ (steak, oxtail stew, or combination grill) and $17.90++ (grilled salmon or pasta). You also get a soup, dessert and coffee/tea.I had the onion soup, a clear, peppery broth chock full of onion and infused with spices such as star anise. Didn't go wrong with tenderloin (slightly thin) with chestnut sauce (yes marron sauce), well-charred and done as ordered. It was vanilla ice cream topped with fruit cocktail for dessert, though I understand that changes.Service was also attentive but not intrusive, and they were cool about our toddler and also supplied a high chair.I'm not sure whether dinner portions are bigger or tastier, but for a lunch set, you simply can't ask for much more at this price point. Especially when these prices apply on Saturday AND Sunday!

photos.caption: Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Tea
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Set dinner
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Lunch set

D-nEEk63KlvUuJuT_ehryA.text: Good wise fosters was alright. Generous portions, with great deals on drinks till 11pm. Food comes quite fast. The biggest gripe I have with the place is it's incredibly poor waitstaff. They were pretty rude to our company, and kept "indirectly"chasing us out well before closing time. Even though we made our order before their last order, they forgot one drink, and when we requested that they brought the mojito, they insisted that they couldn't make the mojito and offered us a shot because "their liquor license ended at 11" (it was 1040 at that point) and couldn't serve us alcohol... Not too sure about the logic behind that because a shot is still alcohol.

hY5uV6wpe9Rh40tQ-nB-Og.text: About Foster's, I only have this to say, that it's been around a long time and they have to be given credit for doing the same thing without fiddling with the standard document too much.  The restaurant has been Foster's since 1960, but it of course has not been run continuously by the same ownership over that period of time.  The current owners have run fosters for the last 13 years or so and have done a creditable job of keeping standards buoyant in this Holland Village institution, especially one of Fosters' pedigree.Looking over the newspaper styled menu, I notice that there are options, quite a lot of them actually besides grilled steer, which always leads me to be suspicious of a place that calls itself a steakhouse.  Of course there are many examples of steakhouse menus that are as varied and abundant as a Bali  market bazaar is with knick knacks and still respect their primary business model enough to churn out respectably grilled meat.  I'm just saying that I worry, maybe excessively, when I sit down at an establishment that claims to do steaks and look at the menu and see not a short list of bar food, seafood options and a kids menu, that the beef may not be getting the attention that it deserves.  The worm of doubt starts squirming, making me wonder if maybe the steaks aren't going to be that good given the vast inventory of perishables that must be stocked to keep this menu afloat and of course, what the turn over on product, especially the steaks at such a joint would be.  I'm just saying that I worry...maybe excessively...maybe needlessly.If you've read my other reviews, you'll know that ambience really isn't an issue for me.  I'll squat in some dung hole if there's a spiritual experience in a bowl in the offing.  I'm just saying that it would've been nice for for the fans to have been turned on and maybe more regular visits by the pest-fogging folks.  None of this really would've registered had the steaks been able to distract me enough.One last caveat before we talk meat.  I've been coming here for some time but had not had the beef in a while, always finding myself here in the afternoon for a nice cream tea instead.Ok, a word or two about the steaks at Foster's now.The Wagyu ribeye with an advertised marbling of 8 is ostensibly US beef.  The steaks are cut too thin.  This has been done to keep the cost of a steak below nose-bleed level, no doubt, but it does beg the question if a Wagyu ribeye should be put on the menu at all, in the first place, if you have to cut it so thin to keep food costs down?  It is my considered opinion that to cut steak that thin is just disrespectful to the ingredient.  If we can't afford to eat properly cut Wagyu steaks, we should just not breed and kill Wagyu cattle.  The thin cut resulted in a steak that was barely rare and what little flavor harbored in the marbling of that thin cut was almost completely smothered by the sautéed onions it was resting on.  You cut meat that thin and rest it on sautéed onions, it could be kangaroo or emu and still passably to the casual eye and palate, be beef.   I still enjoyed the steak, but I think nostalgia had more than a little to do with it.   I would caution someone with no history with Foster's against ordering the Wagyu Ribeye.The USDA Ribeye was similarly thinly cut and smothered in the same sautéed onions, too far gone to be able to show off just how good (or bad) this beef actually was.  One other thing is that when you cut steaks that thin, the gristle starts to show its not so pleasant face more prominently than it should throughout the gastronomic performance of a steak dinner.  Not outright unpleasant, but a little jarring. I suppose if you're comparing this to what passes for steak at hawker center western food in Singapore, then this is pretty good; but not three times as good because this is what the ribeye costs at Foster's.  Again, I question the valuation of the product and where Foster's is pitching it's standard for steak cookery, what it's target audience might be.  Again, my experience here was saved by rose-tinted nostalgia.Nostalgia it seems can be the basis for a viable business model, especially when your custom is food and beverage.  While I cannot abide tweaking established culinary traditions, I would advise the current ownership to rethink how it's doing beef and steaks in particular.  Singaporeans now have been exposed to the intoxicatingly decadent flavors in a 6-8 oz tataki of prime Wagyu, they know that the very best ingredient, prepared with care and an in-depth knowledge of the ingredient, can be wonderful even in small quantities, that it's not always the biggest, bulkiest cut that'll be good.  Maybe now would be a good time to think about ratcheting up the quality of the beef and doing away with the presentation and the needless extras that don't make for an exceptional steak experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. USDA ribeye. Too thinly cut for me.
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Wagyu ribeye. Again pretty thinly cut.

OB6v2l72vQnr96-GraTE1w.text: Tucked in a corner at Holland V, this little cafe that serves English classics like steaks, ribs and pasta. I'm really not sure if the rest of the food is good because i only go there for their scones. My only comment on the other dishes is that they smell really good, especially that lobster bisque. Yums..On a good day, the outdoor seating is not too bad. I reckon it would be nicer in the cooler evenings for a gathering with friends. I like that it is very casual and cosy. Fosters serves the cheapest high tea in Singapore. This is not the usual three-tiered high tea many hotels offer. What do you expect for a mere $10.90++? Here is Foster's explanation of the difference between afternoon tea and high tea. And this is what you get in the set- 2 scones, a toasted fruit cake (i love toasted goods. All things taste better toasted ie banana cakes. Swear by it!), 2 savory sandwiches and either tea/coffee. Sounds like a lot right? Well it is! I usually am satisfied after 1.5 scones but that's me. The rest of the stuff are just mediocre. If you don't want the rest, you can get the scones on their own. It's $2 or is it $2.50 for 1 but the minimum order is 3. Perfect for sharing. Extremely crunchy on the outside (i eat stuff for the texture, not just the taste alone. Other times purely for the texture. I'm weird that way.). Anyways, it's almost like a rock cake or a muffin top. Crunchy outside, buttery moist inside. Plus it's small, so the crunchy to moist ratio is just right. I love lacquering it with butter and the ones they provide are salted! Yay! So the butter goes on first, then a little of the whipped (no clotted cream here. What do you expect for this price right?). The whipped cream adds a tinge of sweetness which complements the butter. For those with a sweet tooth, have more of the jam. I'm no jam fan. They do a takeaway service as well and we have packed these for picnics previously. Everything comes packed nicely with all the complements and cutlery too. Our friends have nothing but positive feedback for the scones. Make a reservation especially for the weekends because they tend to be packed for tea.

photos.caption: Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Lovely scones
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. The tea set
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Outdoor seats

UncxPJt2HoB42wu_lwnSWA.text: holland village was my village when I was still a kid!look how it has evolved!mrt right at it's door steps really eases somewhat the parking nightmare that has characterised much of it's prior existence.still, best not to drive but mrt with the added advantage of drinking at any of the glut of drinking holes here!anyways, fosters is at the furthest end of the row of shop houses after you surface from the mrt station and just before the stairs leading to the bus stop on holland road.I'll not say I grew up on this stuff as it was a luxury back then and only if and when we got a chance to dine here!fast forward to now and service is the first thing that needs to be highlighted.service here literally varies from the newest, most junior to the super senior supervisor.but nothing the entire motley collection cannot handle.they get things done and questions answered between the four of them!But the most junior staff who happens to be a senior has a lot to learn about service.a total lack of product knowledge is how I would describe her.when asked a question about their steaks she can only answer with 'I'm new here'.the supervisor quickly interjected and took over the ala carte menu orders.fresh from the oven bread rolls were crunchily crusty outside and addictively soft within.Kid's set menu is really worth it in terms of quality, portion and taste.$16++ gets you a nice creamy chock full of mushrooms soup, a choice of mains ranging from chicken tenders, fish and chips, spaghetti bolognese or mushroom & ham omelette and a choice of milkshake(pick the chocolate milkshake!), juice or soda.They do set lunches too but today was my bonus treat to my folks, so ala carte it was.All their steaks are air flown aged steaks served with fresh garden vegetables & potatoes.Daddy had:Wagyu Ribeye Steak $88.00Tender & juicy with marbling score 8most flavourful of the lot!probably leaning towards medium rare rather than medium.Mommy had:US Black Angus Ribeye Steak $42.00Tender & Juicy Ribeye grilled to perfection.The smallest and thinnest slice of the three.and thus a little more done than the medium we asked for.still tasty regardless.I had:Fillet Fantastique $42.00Prime middle cut of the finest fillet served on a bed of crisp, fried onions, crowned with juicy field button mushrooms.most tender cut amongst the three we ordered.I would have much preferred the crispy onions to stay crispy on top rather than become soggy lying below.perfectly medium doners.the baked potatoes that came with each were very fluffy.crispy bacon, you can see, bits, cool tangy sour cream and fresh spring onions.for those who don't like baked ones, their french fries rival mac's!oh, when our steak arrive, the same junior 'senior' staff did not know which steak was which!again using the 'I'm new here' line!again, the other senior 'senior' ones took ownership of the problem and clarified with the chef before giving us the answer.there is definitely a good reason why they have been around since 1960............and their steak is it!

photos.caption: Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Wagyu Ribeye Steak $88.00
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Spaghetti bolognese, kid's set.
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Fish and chips, kid's set.

2hYmvraRO4efsSNLpvyAFQ.text: Its a Friday girls night out and a birthday treat from my girls.Been here once and the ambience was good. We requested for an outdoor seat and we love it. This restaurant faces the main road and its hiding at a corner but from far away you could see the name Fosters.We order entrees like escargots, oysters and mushroom soup and follow by the main dish steak, spaghetti.We enjoyed our dinner and the service was good.

photos.caption: Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Steak
Photo of Fosters - Singapore, Singapore. Fresh Oyster

3X4lCsWT_7w_k2V2ss3Q4Q.text: The afternoon tea with scones, cake and sandwiches is the only reason we visit, and is in itself worth the 5 star rating.The scones are firm on the outside and crumbly inside, with the right amount of (minimal) sweetness. The cakes are also very light and flavorful - we have sampled the carrot cake and fruit cake so far and both get top marks.The service staff is friendly and helpful, making our visits enjoyable every time.Haven't tried much of their main courses other than the chicken pot pie, which was decent. The fries are excellent, and go well with the all day Happy hour, which has decent prices and options by Singapore standards.Update:Recently came here for lunch. The lunch special is great value (ordered the steak - just the right size, preceded by an excellent mushroom soup). Special also includes a nice coconut ice cream and coffee/tea. The BH ordered the Chicken a la Kiev, fried and infused with garlic herb butter, which was excellent. The next generation dug into the equally tasty fried chicken and fries. A very nice afternoon, I must say, especially when paired with the happy hour drink special.

XMcb3nEBU2fWAtlyyNUa9Q.text: Fosters in Holland Village used to have the tagline of "English Rose Café" but they have since changed that and have become more of a steakhouse. I have not had dinner here, but I have come for tea and drinks. They have a nice happy hour special, which is a variety of cocktails, 2 for $15. Pretty worth it if you ask me. Ive been here for high tea and unfortunately it was not that great. The sandwiches and scones were really dry and nothing great. However I really like their outdoor garden area. Its really nice and relaxing and a nice place to chill.

geRAveLhy85eblzh7wduOw.text: Fosters is a Holland Village stalwart, having been located in a corner of the village for as long as I can remember. It is primarily known for its British grub - especially its tea set. The Devonshire Cream Tea Set comprises of two scones served with butter, strawberry jam, luscious fresh cream, finger sandwiches and a choice of coffee or tea. Priced at $11, it is one of the cheaper tea sets available in Singapore. Do not come for tea though expecting to be full. Portions are tiny, but I suppose that is what you get for paying just $11. Atmosphere wise, the restaurant feels a bit contrived - at night, tiki torches are lit up outside as a way of inviting customers to dine there. But I suppose the reason why Fosters has remained open for so long is because it provides a quiet respite from the crowds in ever busy Holland Village.

aRxfFAwmTMD15lTiUiOXwQ.text: Foster's ambience is really perfect for those looking for somewhere relatively quieter in Holland Village where seats are comfortable and the service also good. The high tea here is really fantastic: try the scones, which are served hot with jam and butter, along with any type of tea/coffee. Friends and I have agreed that the scones here are one of the best we have had. Opening hours: Sun-Thurs 11am-11pm, Fri-Sat 11-1am.
